claim: If you travel to France and Denmark, you'll need to change dollars into euros and krone.

supporting.text: France uses the euro as its official currency, requiring currency exchange from dollars to euros.

attacks.text: France uses the euro as its official currency, requiring currency exchange from dollars to euros.
Many travelers use credit cards that automatically handle currency conversion, reducing the need for physical currency exchange.
Credit cards may charge foreign transaction fees or offer unfavorable exchange rates, making physical currency exchange preferable in some cases.
Some banks and currency exchange services allow travelers to pre-order euros before departure, avoiding the need for exchange upon arrival.
Pre-ordering currency may still involve fees or less favorable rates compared to local exchange options in France.

supporting.text: Denmark uses the Danish krone as its official currency, requiring currency exchange from dollars to krone.

attacks.text: Denmark uses the Danish krone as its official currency, requiring currency exchange from dollars to krone.
Many businesses in Denmark accept euros, reducing the need to exchange dollars into krone.
Euros are only accepted in limited tourist areas, and most transactions still require Danish krone.
Some credit cards offer direct currency conversion, eliminating the need for physical exchange.
Credit card currency conversion often includes high fees, making physical exchange preferable.

supporting.text: The euro is the legal tender in France, making it necessary to exchange dollars for euros when traveling there.

attacks.text: The euro is the legal tender in France, making it necessary to exchange dollars for euros when traveling there.
Some businesses in France accept dollars, especially in tourist-heavy areas, reducing the need for full currency exchange.
Even if some businesses accept dollars, the exchange rates offered are typically unfavorable compared to official currency exchange services.
Digital payment methods like credit cards eliminate the need for physical currency exchange in many cases.
Credit card transactions often include foreign transaction fees and dynamic currency conversion charges, making cash exchange still preferable in some situations.

supporting.text: The Danish krone is the legal tender in Denmark, making it necessary to exchange dollars for krone when traveling there.

attacks.text: The Danish krone is the legal tender in Denmark, making it necessary to exchange dollars for krone when traveling there.
Many businesses in Denmark accept euros or credit cards, reducing the necessity to exchange dollars for krone.
Even if some businesses accept euros or credit cards, many small shops and local services still require payment in krone.
Travelers can use multi-currency debit cards that automatically convert dollars to krone at competitive rates, bypassing traditional currency exchange.
Multi-currency debit cards may have hidden fees or unfavorable exchange rates compared to local currency exchange services.

supporting.text: Currency exchange is required when traveling to countries with different official currencies, such as France (euro) and Denmark (krone).

attacks.text: Currency exchange is required when traveling to countries with different official currencies, such as France (euro) and Denmark (krone).
Some travelers may use multi-currency credit cards or digital payment methods that automatically handle currency conversion without physical exchange.
Multi-currency cards often have hidden fees or unfavorable exchange rates, making traditional currency exchange more cost-effective in many cases.
In border regions or tourist areas, merchants may accept multiple currencies directly, reducing the need for exchange.
Acceptance of foreign currencies is typically limited to major currencies like USD or EUR, and often at poor exchange rates, making local currency preferable.
